results.title: La Bijouterie Jacquelin = Jacquelin Jeweller
results.brief_description:
Vicdocq is back in Paris, with poor old Flambart forever on his trail. After a close encounter with the police, Vidocq seeks refuge in a jewellery shop which happens to belong to Jacquelin, an old army pal. Jacquelin immediately hires Vidocq to work in the shop where his past experiences as a convict proves useful to fend off swindlers of all kind. Vidocq also becomes quite taken by Jacquelin’s upstairs neighbour, Annette.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Leonce Corne, Jacques Bodoin.

results.title: La Baraque Aux 36 Etoiles = the 36 Stars Fair Booth
results.brief_description:
Annette finally reaches the town of Mezieres and finds a job in a travelling circus. She is preparing an escape plan for Vidocq. The plan involves seducing the prison governor who has installed what he thinks is a failsafe alarm system in the prison: a bell that can be actionned from the corridor.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Bruno Balp, Camiret, Germaine Delbat, Pierre Tornade.

results.title: L.S. Lowry
results.brief_description: The work of L.S. Lowry, a Manchester-born artist, who has lived and worked in that area all his life. He has been described as an English ‘primitive’, but he is first and foremost a painter closely related to the world he knows. Shows many examples of his painting and reveals much of the artist’s personality and his relationship to his work.

results.title: L'une et L'autre = the Other One
results.brief_description:
A young actress, with a rather fragile personality, borrows her sister’s identity in order to break-up with her current lover.

Credits: Producer, Nicole Stephane ; director, Rene Allio ; writers, Rene Allio, Gerard Pollicand ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Claude Dauphin, Malka Ribowska, Francoise Prevost, Christian Alers.

results.title: L'Orfeo
results.brief_description: This opera, sung in Italian, was written by Claudio Monteverdi under the commission of the Duke of Mantua, who wanted the legend of Orfeo, revived in the previous century, set to music. Monteverdi combines dramatic tension, eloquent expression of human passions and formal variety in his setting of Alessandro Stiggio’s libretto. The direction, staging and design is by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle. Features singers Pillippe Huttenlocher (Orfeo), Dietlinde Turban (Euridice), Trudeliese Schmidt (Musica/Speranza), Roland Hermann (Apollo), Glenys Linos (Proserpina), Werner Groschel (Plutone), Hans Franzen (Caronte), Suzanne Calabro (Ninfa) and the Monteverdi Ensemble of the Zurich Opera House conducted by Nikolaus Harnoncourt. No English subtitles.

results.title: L'intrepide = the Intrepid
results.brief_description:
Didier, a surgeon in a Paris hospital, saves the life of Canello, a famous gangster. In order to show Didier how grateful he really is, Canello offers to eliminate Lydie, Didier’s overbearing fiancee. The contract on Lydie must be executed during an overnight train trip. But at the last minute, Lydie gives her seat to an other woman. Didier must now save the woman from becoming a victim of Canello.

Credits: Producer, Alain Darbon ; director, Jean Girault ; writer, Jacques Wilfried, Andre Versini, Rene Versini ; photography, Guy Suzuki ; music, Raymond Lefevre.
Cast: Louis Velle, Claudine Auger, Juliette Mills, Roger Hanin, Michel Galabru.

results.title: L'incoronazione di Poppea
results.creator_credit: Peter Hall, Robin Lough, BBC-TV and Glyndebourne Productions
results.brief_description: A dramatic opera of passion and betrayal, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” by Claudio Monteverdi, libretto by Francesco Busenello, tells the amoral story of the Roman Emperor Nero’s love affair with the scheming and seductive Poppea. Maria Ewing plays the manipulative and evil Poppea and Dennis Bailey is Nerone, her Emperor lover, with a supporting cast including Cynthia Clarey, Robert Lloyd, Elizabeth Gale, Dale Duesing. Features the Glyndebourne Chorus and the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Raymond Leppard who is also responsible for making this modern edition of the opera. Includes an introduction by Peter Hall and a translated printed program in English and Italian. Sung in Italian. Recorded for television as part of the Glyndebourne Festival series.

results.title: L'Ile de la Cite
results.creator_credit: John Seabourne and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An American girl visits the Ile de la Cite, the quais de la Seine and Ile Saint-Louis and has tea with a French friend. Conversation with a quayside bookseller, explanations of the island’s monuments and buildings and a humorous incident involving a phone call are also included. In French langauge.

results.title: L'idiot = the Idiot
results.brief_description:
Russian prince Muichkine returns to St. Petersburg after a stay in a Swiss mental hospital. Blissfully unaware of the greater social problems of his country, the prince believes that love and goodness reign supreme around him. He becomes betrothed to an innocent young girl while trying to save a less-innocent woman from her downfall. Jealousy and his own naivete conjoin to bring about an unimaginable tragedy. ‘L’idiot’ was remade in Japan by Akira Kurosawa (1951) and in Russia by Ivan Pyriev (1958).

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Charles Spaak, Georges Raewsky ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Thiriet, V. de Butzow.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Edwige Feuillere, Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier, Marguerite Moreno, Jean Debucourt, Sylvie.

results.title: L'homme Qui Ment = the Man Who Lies
results.creator_credit: Alain Robbe-Grillet, Maurice Urbain and Samy Halfon
results.brief_description:
Boris Varissa arrives in a small Central European village, used as a haven by local Resitance fighters. He sweet talks his way into the good graces of a family in mourning after the deeath of their son Jean, a Resistance fighter. This avant garde feature leaves the viewer to decide if Boris is telling the truth or covering up for his deeds leading to the death of the heroic Resistance fighter. Awards: Berlin International Film Festival (1968): Best Male Performance for Jean-Louis Trintignant.

Credits: Producers, Maurice Urbain, Samy Halfon ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Igor Luther ; music, Michel Fano ; editor, Bob Wade.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Sylvie Breal, Dominique Prado, Ivan Mistrik, Sylvia Turbova, Catherine Robbe-Grillet, Zuzana Kocurikova, Jozef Kroner, Julius Vasek.
